pros: I liked my teammates, my manager and my benefits. Had more good experiences than bad, but I had to get out of there in order to advance my career in Workday.
cons: Utilization always came first before talent development, quality of projects was poor and IBM core was already stretched for senior level Workday consultants because many of them already left. There was also no structure for advancement or learning if you were new. No mentors, or training path. There was no way to get yourself off the bench to pick up more hours doing other Workday projects or post production support. You get placed where your manager decides they need the billable hours most. Sometimes you are forced to get "cross trained" and never get to do Workday again. Other Workday partners don't operate like this. I don't recommend if you're new to Workday.

job_title: Digital Development Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros: They've been around for a long time so it's unlikely to go belly up. If you're comfortable going through a year of feeling in the dark it's probably grand. The lads that referred me were happy to say that the 'first year at IBM is probably going to be slow'.
cons:
Onboarding didn't happen until 6 weeks in. I've felt on my own for the six months I've worked for the company regardless. Manager put me on the spot in front of stakeholders asking what my expected results were: I had no clue as I just started. All meetings seemed to be about shifting blame to someone else. There's no teamwork.

I was creating opportunities as per my job description yet none of these were followed up on by account executives. Once they were finally followed up on the leads weren't interested anymore as they went for a competitor. That's not really my problem but it was made out to be my fault. 

Onboarding when it finally happened was very old school. One of the onboarders went into a discussion before the actual call started by discussing how women "have a less active mind". Another onboarder focused on the fact that he was probably 20 years older and made the entire 1.5h session about how he had experiences that the younger audience didn't. Sales is focused around the BANT framework that is slightly out of style. It's still useful but it's in no way the go to framework for solution based selling.

Zero recognition. I understand things are based around targets but at least something for Christmas would've been nice. A lunch somewhere on the outskirts of Dublin is just shocking for a company this size.

review_title: Don't Work Here. Please Stay Away
pros:
- worked at the client's site which is located in the heart of the city
- payment received on time
- language/ transport allowance can be claimed depending on needs
- 13th month pay provided
- lateral movement possible after one year of service but subjected to type of employment
cons:
Compensation
- very low basic salary
- shift allowance is max RM300 
- yearly increment from RM50-RM100+
- no dental or optical
- 10% co-pay for all your medical claims

Workplace
- very "inspiring" people leaders who encourage vile behaviours among the team
- immature and unprofessional certified PM-Lean Six Sigma-with years of experience "people leaders" who throw tantrums, shouts, harass and bully team members in public
- third party clients treat you like 3rd class citizen even when you are contracted and is dedicated to work for them
- the managers set the team to fail from the start
- favouritism is rampant
- Contract/ FTH staff with good performance do not get to be Regulars but the new hires get to be one
- performers were told they don't get their contract converted to full-time because of budget issues or the accumulated 5 days of sick leaves were too much
- if you're friends with the right people, you will get promoted and/ or increment
- IBM as an organisation is a fraud and highly delusional. They pride themselves being equal opportunity employers but treat their employees differently. You have the Regulars, Fixed Term Hires and Contractors.
- If there is an event for example a Dinner, Contractors are not allowed to attend even though they put in the same effort and work for the same company
- too many incompetent hires. Leads not able to write or speak English to communicate effectively (they're also not given the chance to attend training to help them improve on their skills)
- if you're a "yes" man and have no honour or integrity and ambition is to spread toxicity by bullying and harassing others you will go far and prosper to build a legacy in this organisation

review_title: Good place to get your feet wet in the tech world
job_title: Content Director in New York, NY
pros:
- IBMers are known for being genuine, nice people. I haven't experienced cattiness, aggression, or any other negative interactions.
- Brand recognition is high--having the name on your resume is good even if the company isn't as prolific as it once was
- There's a big emphasis on professional development with endless resources
- Excellent work/life balance--I rarely work past 5 PM
- Big budgets to try out different marketing efforts
- Working with brilliant, well-educated, respected SMEs is both humbling and exciting
cons:
- IBM is an enormous legacy tech company governed by bean counters, compliance officers, legal teams, and others who minimize our risk. It can be over-bearing at times. Processes always change, and usually not for the better.
- Lack of junior support on most teams. You'll have director-level and lead-level employees stretched thin because they're still doing the same responsibilities even after they're promoted
- Some department execs are lifers (20+ years) which is good and bad. They know the inner machinations, but also tend to be less risk averse or have limited understanding of how marketing happens outside our company
.- We are using email software older than I am and have no plans to migrate off the platform anytime soon.
- IBM has an uncertain future. While other tech companies are booming we're reducing in size. How is that possible?

job_title: DevOps Engineer/Systems Engineer in Poughkeepsie, NY
pros:
- The work/life balance (especially for a systems engineer) is amazing. There are times when things are hot and when they are pretty cool. In all, I will rank them high in this area.
- In my experience, I had access to all kinds of learning resources. Self development is a big deal it appears. I had access to all kinds of materials from text books, to articles, to lectures, etc through the IBM learning portal. Oh boy did i milk that thing!
- I had the opportunity of working various kinds of projects which also helped so much in my professional development. 
- I had the opportunity of trying out new devops application and practices because there is preponderance of hardware resources that enabled me to do this. (Mind you, this may not be the case for everybody). My position (systems engineer, gave me access to a lot of compute resources and placed me at the frontline of problems.
- The company also paid for all my education expenses that saw me obtain my master degree (I don't know if they still do this)
- A lot of solid, old technology talents - They may have problems with doing things the new way though (I mean driving Infrastructure as code, self healing automation etc)
cons:
- The chain of commands can make it difficult to innovate. I had to push and pull to drive change (more importantly though, your direct manager is very important here. My manager was not the best at advocating for her workers).
- The pay can also be very low (I got a little over double the amount I made while in IBM as an advisory Engineer when I transitioned to another company). For the last three years of my total 8, I was without pay raise.
- They are also beginning to go in the direction of other 'woke' corporate cultures across the US by driving "diversity and inclusion" to its insane end. They have adopted the CRT training in their learning modules basically attempting to brainwash members of staff along the 'woke' thought-process.
- The performance criteria and measurement are very nebulous and quite difficult to navigate (for me, your experience may be different).

review_title: IBM is where your career goes to die a slow and meaningless death
pros:
- they pay money in exchange for work
- people are impressed when you say you've worked at IBM
- you have the ability to learn a lot of things and gain exposure to a lot of tech
cons:
- extremely difficult to get a promotion or move laterally within the company unless you're friends with the right people. the internal jobs board is meaningless and broken.
- org is so top heavy that your managers will have no power to make positive changes within the org. the real decision making power lies within the manager of the manager of your manager's manager. Your own manager is just a puppet there to make you feel like your words mean something and serve as a punching bag so that upper management is isolated from the discontent of the lower class.
- IBM will not give meaning salary increases even if your original role is greatly expanded and you are doing the work of 4 other people concurrently. If you are in a lousy division, expect that this will not change.
- IBM has this cult mentality over 'badges', which are obtained via completing small mini courses that do not test you for real skill aptitude. You need to obtain a lot of these in order to gain visibility in IBM. Basically, you need to wear above minimum pieces of flair.

Your own manager is just a puppet there to make you feel like your words mean something and serve as a punching bag so that upper management is isolated from the discontent of the lower class.
- IBM will not give meaning salary increases even if your original role is greatly expanded and you are doing the work of 4 other people concurrently. If you are in a lousy division, expect that this will not change.
- IBM has this cult mentality over 'badges', which are obtained via completing small mini courses that do not test you for real skill aptitude. You need to obtain a lot of these in order to gain visibility in IBM. Basically, you need to wear above minimum pieces of flair.

pros: Work life balance guaranteed at IBM.  IBM Cloud solutions have already been introduced into various parts of the UK’s National Health Service, contributing to the efficient and secure running and delivery of care to patients. One such example is NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) which employs IBM Business Process Manager (BPMoC) and Operational Decision Manager on Cloud (ODMoC) to maximise utility within the organisation’s structure. There are multiple benefits, and include the streamlining of delivery, maximised utilisation and equity of organ allocation nationwide, and the freeing up of vital resources. October 2015 was a seminal moment for the partnership, with the first transplant of a heart allocated according to the new scheme taking place. Innovation did not halt there, and NHSBT is exploring additional possibilities afforded by IBM’s cloud solutions, including expanding platform capabilities to encompass kidney and pancreas transplants.
cons: Locked with IBM cloud and tools in most of the IBM core projects

cons:
Upon passing the Java Bootcamp, they hold our employment til August/September even though other companies are already onboarding during the Pandemic.
Even though our bootcamp is for Java, most of us, including myself, did not get a Java position or atleast something programming related.
We are forced to work during weekends, prior to the client's request. 
No immediate OT pay.
If you're looking for a stable career path, think twice before entering here, there might be a possibility that you won't get what you want from the start or not at all.

pros:
- Employee Friendly; lots of emphasis on D&I
- Fertile Grounds for Growth; lateral and vertical
- Opportunity to grow by jumping across portfolios (not rare to find IBMers who have worked a mind-boggling number of positions/job-roles across technologies/competencies)

- Robust repository of tools for online collaboration
- Opportunities for job-rotation/stretch assignments
- Global Corporate Social Responsibility Program
- Exposure to global teams since most projects run in matrixed environment
cons:
- Lack of a global "promotion" policy; think "promotion" every FIVE years in some countries
- Poor annual compensation when compared to market standard, regardless of established subject matter expertise
- Negligible annual salary hike (unless you're very high-up in the echelon)
- Incredible disparity in income between those who grow organically and those who are hired from outside
- Not the best appraisal process; the definition of "Met" and "Exceeded" is subjective and changes oft 
- Leadership are an entitled lot (think developing countries)

job_title: Senior Account Executive in London, England
pros:
- Good base salaries
- Very flexible working conditions, even for recent graduates
cons:
- Restructuring ALL the time - I have been at IBM for less than 2 years and have been under threat of redundancy twice already
- Incredibly poor sales leadership - you are just a number and the focus is purely on next quarters achievement, not your overall success/development
- Company is in decline - falling revenues mean that any of the softer benefits employees once might have had (travel, events, expenses, team drinks/meals, international job opportunities - basically any perks of working for a big tech company) no longer exist
- Antiquated internal systems/processes - everyone in IBM is reliant on their network because the internal tools/systems are appalling, and it takes 3-5-7 days to get ANYTHING done. It is the 21st century and yet we are still using Lotus Notes and don't have a fully functioning CRM system. Staggering.
- awful customer experience - everything is slow, cumbersome and requires huge amounts of admin. This translates into a very poor customer experience
- Most sellers are underperforming - targets are high, products are good (in some areas) but the systems/processes in place make the job almost impossible. Also, there is zero marketing/BDR support, so do not expect any inbound/warm leads unless you are working on a top account

review_title: Loosing Brand Image due to  unhealthy work environment and biased leadership
pros:
IBM is a Brand. 
I was a proud IBMer and will always be proud of working with an esteemed organization like IBM.
A place to explore opportunities under right leadership. 
A Place grow knowledge and gain practical experience which yields great professional career and future.
cons:
Leadership.
Hyderabad Leadership is the worst when compared to Chennai and Bangalore.
Hence no new projects / good project are coming to Hyderabad.
Only the left overs are give to Hyd and the rest is pulled to Chennai & Bangalore.
Dominance of Tamil leadership . They do not allow others to get into their hierarchy . 
Hyderabad HR team is not strong.
Too much of politics at management level.
A good for nothing two time PIP candidate can become a leader, but a strong and talented resource is pushed down. Proves local Leadership fears of letting talent grow.

pros: Good Flexibility about working hours, shifts, Work From Home Opportunities at the time of essential requirement. Good support from management during personal, family and health related issues.
cons: Technical learning opportunities are less and such requests are not entertained. Switching accounts/projects etc are very difficult. Even if you arrange personal self funded training, its not possible to get into your desired roles and responsibilities hence your personal learnings wont be utilized and eventually you forget everything you learnt by yourself. You need to continue to follow the same old orthodox process and policies which are most of them irrelevant in the currently changing environment. You cannot ask Why because that concept is not there there at all. Salary revision/appraisal is not there at all hence you will be continuing getting the same package year after year with no initiative from the management side. Too much frugality in place.

review_title: Great place to work, but your mileage may vary
job_title: Product Management in New York, NY
pros:
- Ability to work on exciting projects, with big clients, and some very new cool technology
- Lot of great, smart people to work with and learn from. Very rarely will you be the smartest person in the room, and that is great for a career in product management.
- IBM is B2B and big on integrity, you aren't going to have to do anything dubious, and there's a great permission structure and set of systems for maintaining that.
- You can move up diagonally and explore adjacent careers or roles. If you feel like you've hit diminishing returns in Product Management, you can get into Sales, Strategy, M&A, Partnership, Development, etc, if you work at it a bit.
cons:
- IBM is a big company, 300K+ employees world-wide. Parts of IBM are extremely well managed and up-to-date, with healthy cultures, others have awful outdated processes, terrible cultures, or management that lead through fear instead of intelligence. As a candidate, you need to scrutinize who you would be working for, the culture of the team, how it and you are measured. It is not worth working for a bad part of IBM.
- Diversity could be better. A lot of great improvement over the last few years, but more work required.

review_title: Culture and People is the best
pros:
What I like the most is about the culture and people. IBM encourages employee to invest back to ourselves. Various complimentary learnings (eg: Soft skill – communication, presentation, IT related – R language, Python, create own chatbot …..) are available and it could be overwhelmed sometime. It is up to individual to learn as per their own speed and arranged accordingly. The company also advocacy to embrace differences, appreciate ideas, and respect each individual. 
Due to the pandemic, many working parent struggle to juggle btw family and work at home at the same time when school and child care centre are closed. Good support received from management and teammate, also free consultation is provided to take care each employees.
cons:
There are 2 hours differences btw country I support and where I stay. Hence, I could start late by attending family matter first in the morning. Of course, it also means that I will finish the day 2 hours later than others, which is fair. In terms of public holiday, it is better to follow one's supporting country, not where you stay. Pro, one could avoid crowd at everywhere during public holiday and replacement day will be provided. Con, it may be difficult to attend some event / gathering held on public holiday. But this could be discussed & arranged with own teammates. 
IT & Tech is a fast-changing industry, employee is encourage to learn and stay relevant in the industry. It could be stressful sometime, but this is more self-imposed kinda stress, not from the management / company.

review_title: Data Center Technician for IBM Cloud
job_title: Server Build Technician III in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
Training is good and there is a lot of resources for continued education.
The work load is balanced, and management should be receptive to a desire to do more for DC Operations.
Being a fulltime IBM employee you will receive the standard employee benefits (PTO, 401k, health/dental/vision).
cons:
Career growth is limited by how much of a priority you are to your manager. Communication is difficult and often obscured when trying to develop internally within IBM. Perhaps due to Data Center Operations being physically separate (and sometimes temporally) from other teams, and IBM Cloud being a separate "child company" acquired and in a continuous state of integration into IBM.
Based on the last couple years, full-time hires are decreasing in favor of contract workers without benefits. IBM should offer full-time employment on completion of training, but this could also change.
New hires are usually stuck on evening or night shift once training has progressed enough (1-2 months), moving off this will again depend on how well you communicate with management, or it may get you moved to a different DC site.
You are responsible for the office environment and equipment maintenance. If you and your coworkers don't stay on top of it, expect tools to degrade. You will have to be your own IT, while also dealing with IBM remote help desk (my experiences with them have been poor, regardless of the time of day I called in).

pros:
+ Good PTO package
+ Access to mountains of free training materials (Udemy, O'Reilly, Coursera, etc)

+ When you have the right manager, the work is pretty fun.

cons:
- Went to hiring contractors around 2 years ago and knee-capped staffing.
-Low staffing numbers at slower sites means *when* you get to take PTO is limited.
-Performance metrics for ticket work is based on meaningless data points that defy any understanding of KPAs
-Contractors get hired, find better jobs, then leave, leaving you holding the bag if you're permanent.

job_title: Delivery Project Executive in Toronto, ON
pros: I started with IBM in 1979 as a student and they supported me during my studies until I joined full time in 1984 to the IBM Laboratory doing advance software development. They are incredibly support of training and career development with access to many types of training programs and an annual requirement to take at least 40 hours of training per year. In 1986, IBM supported my studies for a business degree at York University, allowing me to take up to 2 days off a week to accelerate my studies with me obtaining my degree in 1996. I did leave IBM for a few years to pursue some special interest opportunities, but returned in 2012 into Global Services where I have led many fascinating engagements across Canada at BC Hydro, Shell Canada, TD Bank and currently the Government of Canada Phoenix payroll system.
cons: I don't have any concerns about IBM. All companies always have their peculiarities and expectations but as long you understand them and they are in line with your personal beliefs and career objectives, it works out just fine. Working at IBM though is more than a job, it is a career for everyone at all levels. Continual training and growth is expected, even during very busy times fulfilling client commitments.

pros:

cons:
- I've kind of been left to my own devices since 1 year and 3 months in. I'm happy to take ownership of the product I work on, but I don't feel like my technical skills are up to snuff without having a senior help me learn what I don't know.
- Promotions weren't hard but they aren't easy either, there's only so many positions to go around.
- A decent amount of turnover in the sense of people leaving IBM for something better.

- It's a big, bloated machine. It works, just not always quickly.
- Good base pay, but no other compensation
